thread.title: NFL wrap: Washington enjoys wild victory
thread.title_full: NFL wrap: Washington enjoys wild victory

title: NFL wrap: Washington enjoys wild victory
text:
Pages: 1 2 > display on one page 
There were plenty of reasons for quarterback Kirk Cousins and the Redskins to believe this game was not going to go their way Sunday at Landover, Md. 
They trailed by 24 in the second quarter. They had been outscored by 43 points in third quarters so far this season. Cousins hadn’t thrown more than one touchdown pass in any game this season. 
At halftime, coach Jay Gruden — who had called the matchup against Tampa Bay as a "code red" situation — lit into his players. 
Something finally clicked. Cousins completed three second-half touchdown passes, including the go-ahead score to Jordan Reed with 24 seconds left, as Washington won, 31-30, for the largest comeback in franchise history. 
"Everybody was pretty upset. Jay was livid," left tackle Trent Williams said about a loud halftime locker room. 
Tampa Bay’s Jameis Winston, the No. 1 pick in this year’s draft, was 21-for-29 for 297 yards and two first-half touchdowns. 
CHIEFS 23, STEELERS 13 (at Kansas City, Mo.) — Alex Smith threw for 251 yards and a touchdown and Cairo Santos kicked three field goals as Kansas City ended a five-game losing streak. 
Steelers coach Mike Tomlin said that quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who is out with a knee injury, should be ready to go next week against Cincinnati. 
DOLPHINS 44, TEXANS 26 (at Miami Gardens, Fla.) — Dolphins quarterback Ryan Tannehill extended his two-game streak to 25 consecutive completions, an NFL record, before he threw his only incompletion in the fourth quarter. 
NFL.com reported that Houston running back Arian Foster is out for the year after injuring his Achilles tendon. 
PANTHERS 27, EAGLES 16 (at Charlotte, N.C.) — Cam Newton took another step toward rewriting the NFL record book as Carolina improved to 6-0 for the first time in franchise history. 
Newton threw for a touchdown and ran for another score, marking the fourth time this season and 28th time in his career he has done so — three behind Hall of Famer Steve Young for the league record. 
VIKINGS 28, LIONS 19 (at Detroit) — Teddy Bridgewater threw for a season-high 316 yards and two TDs for Minnesota as the Vikings won an NFC North game on the road for the first time in three years. 
Lions QB Matthew Stafford had X-rays on his left hand after the game. 
RAIDERS 37, CHARGERS 29 (at San Diego) — Derek Carr threw three TD passes, including a 52-yarder to Amari Cooper, and Oakland turned two interceptions into 10 points. 
FALCONS 10, TITANS 7 (at Nashville, Tenn.) — Matt Ryan threw for 251 yards and a TD pass and Devonta Freeman ran for 116 yards to lead the Falcons. 
Titans cornerback Jason McCourty, the former St. Joseph and Rutgers star, came out after suffering a hamstring injury. 
RAMS 24, BROWNS 6 (at St. Louis) — St. Louis rookie Todd Gurley rushed for 128 yards and his first two touchdowns. 
Cleveland’s Johnny Manziel came on late in relief of quarterback Josh McCown (shoulder). 
SAINTS 27, COLTS 21 (at Indianapolis) — Drew Brees threw for 255 yards and one touchdown and Khiry Robinson ran for two scores for New Orleans. 
JAGUARS 34, BILLS 31 (at London) — Blake Bortles threw a TD pass to Allen Hurns with 2:16 left as Jacksonville rallied. © 2015 North Jersey Media Group Tags:
